On 9 March 2011 07:10, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:>
> I see what you're saying about the Junk DNA perhaps providing a special kind of
> randomness. But one thing I find a little confusing is the idea that there is a special
> kind of random distribution that is better than other random distributions. If that is true,
> then doesn't it require some information to encode what that distribution is? And if it
> does need to be chosen from some special distributions, and those distributions are
> captured by Junk DNA, which ends up being expressed, then why is it called "Junk
> DNA?" Couldn't we essentially tell the same story in a simpler way by saying, "a
> subset of DNA encodes the initial weight distribution in the brain?" What then makes it
> junk? And why use the word random either?

Junk DNA is a horrible term with multiple connotations, so perhaps
some clarification would help here (drawing from what I know).
Originally DNA was considered to code for proteins and nothing else,
so all the DNA that didn't code for proteins (which is quite a lot I
believe) was thought to be junk that was just 'in it for the ride' so
to speak.

Later on it turned out that some of this junk DNA had regulatory roles
- e.g. controlling the expression of protein coding genes. Think of
the distinction between program data and program instructions in
computers - that's probably a crude generalisation but that's the
general principle. (If anyone wants to step in and correct me here I'd
be more than happy).

This stilll left a load of other DNA which came about through
accumulated replication errors and chunks of ancient viruses that
perhaps infected our ancestors in the recent past (up to 100's of
thousands of years ago) or much further back when we were still worms
crawling around in mud :)  The point is that it's DNA that has no
functional use, it doesn't normally get expressed in any way. This to
me is closest to being true junk DNA and it's possible that it just
got replicated and not used through much of our evolutionary
history... then we started to evolve big brains and (the theory goes)
some parts of this junk start to get used as a source of arbitrary
complexity for brain physiology.

If the theory is true then some of that junk DNA came to be used and
is therefore no longer junk (albeit interpreted in a novel new way
distinct from it's original context and purpose). Essentially it's not
part of the 'main-sequence' DNA that was functional for our entire
evolutionary history - the DNA that optimised and accumulated slowly
and incrementaly.

----

Yeh the word random is not really appropriate either - I think
'arbitrary complexity' is a more accurate term, but perhaps others
disagree or have a better description? Also as a side note I want to
point out that distribution curves are not complete descriptors of
types of randomness - I'm not sure to what degree I'm stating the
obvious to folks on here, but just to be clear - there are other
factors at play, e.g. you can have two RNGs with the same distribution
curve but very different properties, so taking gaussian curves, an RNG
might emit extreme values all clumped together and then mid values all
clumped together so that it's only seen to be gaussian when a very
large number of samples are observed, but it is gaussian and very
distinct from a typical gaussian process/sequence.


> In any case, it still does bring up whether a special activation function inspired by this
> idea might be helpful in establishing some aspect of initial connectivity. I'm guessing
> that if that is true, then the advantage would probably show up more in plastic networks
> than static ones.

Agreed. I don't think it's necessarily black and white but it would
seem to be less applicable to fixed weight networks than plasticity
nets that are using this arbitrary connectivity as a starting point
instead of something that needs to be immediately functional.

Colin.
